Award.AwardTitle: Assessing the neural dynamics of reading in deaf adults

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Reading presents a significant challenge for individuals who are born severely-to-profoundly deaf because they cannot hear the language that is encoded by print. The factors that lead to skilled reading for deaf individuals are currently under debate and not well understood. For hearing individuals, phonological coding and awareness skills appear to be critical for reading success, but these skills are not good predictors of reading proficiency for deaf people. Furthermore, almost nothing is known about the underlying neural processes involved in the transition from identifying visual letter features to accessing word meaning for deaf readers. This project is designed to investigate the brain response to reading in deaf adults and the factors that predict variation in those responses. By identifying factors that do (and do not) affect reading processes, this project will inform educational models of literacy instruction and reading remediation for deaf people. In addition, deafness has a substantial impact on the ability of students to gain access to research careers because of communication roadblocks that hamper interaction with hearing scientists. The principal investigators have deaf-friendly labs (e.g., project staff are fluent in ASL) and provide training that facilitates the entrance of deaf students into scientific and academic fields. Thus, a parallel aim of the project is to increase the representation of deaf people in science by including deaf researchers on the project and by providing an accessible environment for deaf students to gain training and research experience.

With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Karen Emmorey, Dr. Philip Holcomb, and their colleagues will use behavioral and neurophysiological measures to identify what factors predict variations in the brain's response when deaf adults read and recognize written words (e.g., spelling ability, phonological awareness, signing ability, reading speed). Cutting edge source localization techniques will be used to constrain and identify the neural location of the brain's response as measured by electroencephalography (EEG). The project is designed to illuminate the neural dynamics of reading for deaf people who are bilingual in English and American Sign Language and to understand how the neural components of reading are shaped by deafness, i.e., by the changes in visual attention and phonological abilities that result from congenital hearing loss. These discoveries will have theoretical import for understanding the neural plasticity (and invariance) of the reading system, as well as practical implications for developing reading interventions for deaf individuals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Reading is a complex visual and linguistic process that differs for deaf and hearing adults because of their distinct sensory and language experiences. Changes in visual and phonological processing that stem from a lack of auditory input during development can alter the nature of the reading process. In order to understand the flexibility of reading in the brain, this project used event-related potentials (ERPs) to measure the brain’s response to visually presented words. In hearing readers, a brain wave called the “N170” is larger over the left (language) hemisphere and is hypothesized a) to reflect sensitivity to written words (the N170 is larger for words than symbol strings) and b) to shift to the left hemisphere when hearing children learn to map sounds to words. The results showed that for deaf readers, the N170 was similar across the left and right hemispheres near auditory (temporal) regions. The deaf readers had the same reading ability but poorer phonological skills compared to the hearing readers, supporting the hypothesis that for hearing people, the N170 shifts to the left hemisphere due to sound-based reading processes. In addition, better reading ability was associated with a larger right hemisphere N170 over visual (occipital) regions for deaf readers, but for hearing readers better reading ability was associated with a smaller right hemisphere N170. Since the groups were matched on reading ability, this finding suggests that the optimal neural processing of words differs for skilled deaf and hearing readers. Additional studies from this project indicate that both deaf and hearing readers are sensitive to the size of a word’s neighborhood (i.e., the number of similar looking words) and that similar words compete in the brain for recognition.

 

Broader Impacts: The results of this project indicate that the optimal end-state of the brain for skilled reading is not identical for deaf and hearing adults. The reading circuit in deaf adults who have achieved reading success appears to have successfully adapted to reduced auditory phonological input during development by increasing reliance on orthographic-to-semantic mappings and engaging right hemisphere brain regions. The nature of these adaptations creates a neural system that shares core components with the system engaged by hearing readers but may lead to different neural markers of reading skill. Understanding the behavioral and brain patterns associated with skilled reading in deaf adults provides critical clues to how reading skill develops in this population. In addition, the results provide new information for creating reading remediation materials for deaf adults who are poor readers.  Another broader impact of this project is the training and inclusion of an underrepresented group: individuals with hearing loss. Deafness has a substantial impact on the ability of students to gain access to research careers because of communication roadblocks that hamper interaction with hearing scientists. During this NSF project, the researchers have provided a unique educational environment (all communication occurs in American Sign Language), training by both deaf and hearing researcher, and mentoring for several deaf students who gained research skills and experience that have helped them succeed in entering a Ph.D. program or gain employment in a STEM field.
